Dear J. Zheng,

Lane Sharman has been communicating with me by e-mail. While I do not know him in person, based on my research of published news articles and our e-mail exchange, I believe in his version of the truth.

Lane Sharman is the co-founder of San Diego Energy District. His contact information is listed on San Diego Energy District’s website. Feel free to contact him directly if you doubt his authenticity.

Sincerely,

Albert

J. Zheng,

You can google Lane Sharman and compare the photos. Or you can contact Lane Sharman to find out whether this is him or not. His contact information is listed online so it is not difficult to verify if you don't think this is the real Mr. Sharman. Why are all Ping Fu supporters reluctant to do fact-checking?

Everyone,

This is Lane Sharman.

I have to confess that I am very saddened to be accused of promoting dishonesty.

I have a long record of developing trusted relationships with people across all types of business. I practice the golden rule.

I can defend myself on the basis of a long record of fair dealings with all people, from all walks of life and from all ethnicities.

Thank you,

Lane
I remember this story as if it were yesterday, as well as the personal side of the author. Phillips was unique.

Picking and choosing the convenient, while ignoring the inconvenient evidence? That’s mighty liberal of you.

Here’s another stat for you to consider.

Vermont, awash in guns, very loose gun control laws, yet its gun homicide rate (1.3 per 100,000) is not different from those of France, Ireland, UK, Portugal . . . .

WDC, having had gun prohibition for decades, exhibits homicide rate perhaps 20 times greater.

It’s not the guns. It’s the people, with broken & fatherless families.
Thanks for digging up this info.

Divorce rate in Vermont is double the divorce rate in Massachusetts. Massachusetts -- strong gun control, low gun ownership rate, one of the lowest divorce rates in the nation.

Check your stats before posting, people:
http://www.census.gov/compendia/statab/2012/tables/12s0132.pdf

There goes the "strong families" argument. Too bad ...

The places with the highest rate of gun deaths and the highest rates of divorce are poor, rural communities across the South and West. So, you've got drinking, smoking, shooting and philandering going on and then you get up on Sunday morning to repent.

Vermont is an interesting state. Practically no gun control and practically no murder. But that's not a recipe that you can just export to Florida. If we can figure out what Vermont is doing right, I am all for using it as a model.

I think it's the hunter ethic. Most gun owners in Vermont are descended from hunters. Hunters use their guns to kill things and then they walk over and put their hands into the dead body of their kill and pull out its guts.

I think that experience gives you a healthy respect for guns. That respect is obviously lacking in suburban boys who kill things on computer screens. If we were still a nation of hunters, I do not think we would have this problem. Unfortunately, we are not.

I guess you can just say anything as long as you want to make a point!

The general trend is that for almost every state, the cities are blue, while the rural areas are red- i.e. Portland Oregon blue/eastern Oregon red; Denver blue/rural areas red; Austin, Houston, El Paso, Dallas, San Antonio blue/rural Texas red; Philadelphia blue/western and central PA red, NYC blue/Upstate red; Chicago blue/southern Illinois red; etc....It seems like population density is a big factor: in a city the police are always a block away, while in rural Texas or Oklahoma, the Sheriff is usually a 20 minute car ride away.
No, they'd likely kill you.  The morning line is 6 to 1.  Not   impressed? Me, I'm all over 6 to 1 like a cheap suit!

I'm going to make a simple observation.  How many pro GOP states have had school shooting famous enough to come to mind?   How many blue (gun control supporting) states have had a famous shooting?  Columbine was where?  Sandy Hook was where?  Where is Aurora?  Blue states, that's where!!!  Chicago has some of the strictest gun laws in the land, yet their violent crime is off the charts.   Gun control is a state issue anyways.  I can't even tell you when a school shooting ever happened in my state, don't punish me because your blue state is full of psychos.  I own an assault rifle and high capacity mags, haven't thought about shooting anything other than milk jugs.   I support open carry.  I'm pretty sure if an intruder came into my place of business with evil intent and saw my ar-15 strapped to my back they would immediately stand down.  I could save the day with no shots fired.
Threatening a filibuster is nothing more than threatening to short-circuit democracy.    These people are afraid of the vote - so they prevent voting.  Despicable.
Sorry, that's "the rights of 40-50 MILLION Americans" that already have had their 2nd Amendment rights eliminated
the Tx attack was horrible, but how many actually died?  That's the difference.

So, Texas, how many people were KILLED because of this random stabbing yesterday in your state? Not injured, KILLED.

I'll answer that for you, ZERO. 14 people were injured, 2 critically, but no one was killed. I can almost guarantee you that there would be 14 or more killed, not just injured.
Had there been a gun. Sorry, I'm getting my kids ready for school while doing this.

It's an odd omission that Lanza was refused a gun purchase b/c of a background check. Also, it is a misrepresentation to say that guns sold legally always stay in the hands of the owner. That wasn't the case with Lanza. What is the far more serious issue is the general unwillingness to admit that some people who are mentally ill are a threat to others. As children we are forced by law to allow them to go to school where they can victimize or be victimized by others due to their mental illness. I've seen this happen in classrooms where students were terrified, the teacher abused by a teenager.  The last ARD minutes of Lanza's public school experience would most likely reveal an escalating level of delusion. That was the case with Holmes in CO. His parents moved away-care to guess why? Several people knew he was fantasizing  violence, but we aren't allowed to judge even when it means putting innocents in trouble. While it's easy to target guns as the weapon of choice, how do you explain yet another event in TX today.A known eccentric attacked 14 people with a knife? You can take away all the weapons you want, but if we continue to have a societal unwillingness to put those who are dangerous in a place where they can't hurt others, we will continue to see these stories.
We're not holding our breath. We're WORKING, in memory of THE CHILDREN ignored by those who write such casual comments about this matter.We're holding Congress accountable. Join us.
Then House obstruction becomes electoral issue in mid-terms with guns laws as exhibit A, and the Democrats take back the House.

While I agree gun control is an important issue, it seems to be just another distraction by politicians from other important issues like the economy and jobs.  The politicians can always distract with another social issue and people jump on their own side.  Guns do need some controls but it just seems to me another distraction to further divide the 90%.  GAGG has dominated state and national politics for much too long (Guns, Abortions, Gods, and Gays).  Would think as a country we have other important issues to deal with.  And if we consider ourselves a mature democracy GAGG wouldn't even be on the radar.  Voters are so easily manipulated.

My fear is that they are going to pass some watered own background check. It is not the one that is written now. If background checks are not specific, then it is not any good. It has to be clear and specific.

"Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, and Patrick J. Toomey, Republican of Pennsylvania were very near a deal that would most likely serve as an amendment replacing the background check piece of the measure that Mr. Reid is seeking a vote on. Their measure, which would almost certainly appeal to a broader base of members than the one now at the heart of the debate, would include fewer gun buyers in newly expanded checks, but allow for the record keeping that many Republicans have opposed. The two were expected to announce a deal Wednesday."

Democrats, please do not do a rewritten watered down background check. We will know. Just warning you - we are not a stupid electorate. Do not do a watered down background check.

The "common sense" gun laws you support mean that Oregon should have to provide all available information on marijuana users to the federal government - including those who are legally (under Oregon law) consuming and/or growing marijuana for medical purposes.

Even though simple possession/consumption of marijuana is a violation - roughly the equivalent of a parking ticket under Oregon law - under Reid's bill they should be reported as well and will be denied the right to purchase, possess, transport firearms or ammunition.

Sorry Grannie, just because you live alone in a high crime area with thugs waiting to break in and steal your medical marijuana and whatever else they can get don't go thinking you have a right to keep a gun on hand to defend yourself. And if we find out you *do* have one you're looking at ten years in Club Fed - you dangerous felon... 18 USC § 922(g) & (n)

All this cheer-led by Obama and Holder who are doing zero time for their trafficking of thousands of weapons to Mexican drug cartels.

Sorry, Ami - wake up and smell the hypocrisy - the gun controllers' version of "common sense" is about as oxymoronic as "conventional wisdom"

True leadership is doing what is right not what is popular or what will get you re-elected.  Rarely do 90% of the American public agree on anything let alone gun control.  We need our elected leaders to step up and come up with some common sense legislation to protect the majority from the minority when it comes to gun issues.  Be bold, take a stand and show leadership....this is an issue worth compromising on.

I am no longer worried about criminals. I am worried about people like Nancy Lanza. They are the real threat, as we can see from their comments and their chosen representatives in our government.

If gun owners were really against crime and the misuse of firearms, they would be doing everything in their power to make the exercise of their Second Amendment rights safer.

Instead, they are doing everything in their power to ensure that their children are allowed to massacre ours whenever the mood strikes them.

This has nothing to do with guns everything to do with a desire to be free from accountability for ones choices and actions.

They say we are "sheep" but I say they are crybabies who put our Founders and their vision of the citizen soldier to shame.

Better a sheep than a snake in the grass.

A background check would be a real consideration, as in check to confirm that an individual is clear to own a firearm, but that is not what is being presented.  I would suggest becoming more informed on the subject before posting and embarrassing yourself again. Laws designed to address the issue, and would considerable more effective have been pursued, but they are not being considered or discussed because the stated concern is not the point.  If you really were concerned about violence, where are the laws against hammers, knives, bats, cars, pools, sticks, martial arts, boots, medication, etc.

My all-time favorite: "background checks don't work, criminals won't abide by them..." A sterling reason to do away with silly anti-homicide laws...you can pass all the murder laws you want, but people will still kill each other. Sorry, all arguments against any background checks are ridiculous. Paranoia rules these people, big time.
As we have learned to our vast chagrin over too many years, in our fair country "left" "right" and "center" are highly relative terms.

That is unfair, untrue, and disingenuous to the conversation.  Just because someone does not agree with you on the best course of action does not make them  a mental case.  Slandering the other side of  disagreement in this manner smacks of bias and propaganda.
The gun lobby made a very bad decision yo double down on crazy in the wake of Newtown. They offended and alienated everyone who is not a complete mental case.

He thought it a good idea for ordinary guys to have guns.

Perhaps aspects of current proposed gun control legislation would have more support from gun owners (than the oft quoted 90% of the population - who did the polling?) if some aspects of the current laws were relaxed.  For example - In the UK "Police forces usually approve applications for a suppressor for hunting and target shooters, as the risks of litigation for personal injury, especially high-tone deafness resulting from shooting-induced hearing loss, are significant; and noise pollution in general is a problem for shooting sports."  Whereas in the US, as noted in a previous post, permits for a silencer take $200 and a long wait.
